subject: polity
title: Constitutional Amendments - Types, Procedure & Landmark Cases

definition: **Flexible yet rigid**: Easier than USA (rigid), tougher than UK (flexible)
**Balance**: Stability (not too easy) + Adaptability (not too rigid)
whyAmendments: **Judicial interpretation**: SC decisions may require constitutional changes
**Political goals**: Governments amend for their agenda (socialism, emergency, etc.)
statistics: **Most recent**: 106th Amendment 2023 (Reservation in Assemblies/LS for SCs/STs extended 10 years)
**Most amended articles**: Art 14-16 (Equality), Art 19 (Freedoms), Art 31 (Property - repealed)
constitutionalProvision: **Clause (1)**: Parliament may amend by addition, variation, repeal
**Clause (2)**: Procedure for amendment (special majority, state ratification)
**BUT**: Kesavananda (1973) ruled Parliament **cannot destroy basic structure**
content.examTips: **106 Amendments** till 2023. Art 368 provides procedure. Flexible yet rigid. **Basic structure doctrine** (Kesavananda 1973) limits amendment power. 42nd Amendment (1976) = longest; 1st Amendment (1951) = first.

definition: **Simple majority**: More than 50% of members **present and voting**
**No special procedure**: Same as ordinary legislation
**Art 368 NOT required**: These are NOT formal constitutional amendments
**Easiest method**: Parliament can amend on its own
provisions: **Sixth Schedule** (Administration of tribal areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, Mizoram)
**Abolition of second chamber** in states (Art 169 - Legislative Council)
**Use of English language** in Parliament (Art 343 - within 15 years of Constitution, can be extended)
examples: **Reorganization of states**: States created by simple majority laws
**Citizenship Act amendments**: Changes to citizenship rules
**Art 169**: Many states abolished/created Legislative Councils (UP, Bihar, Karnataka, etc.)
content.examTips: **Simple majority**: Present and voting. Mainly for **federal structure** (Art 2-4 states), **citizenship** (Art 5-11), **elections** (Art 324-329), **Scheduled areas** (Art 244, 5th/6th Schedule), **Art 169** (Legislative Council). NOT formal amendment under Art 368.

definition: **Special majority** (Art 368): Two conditions BOTH must be satisfied:
**1. At least 2/3rd majority** of members **present and voting** in each House
**2. Simple majority** (more than 50%) of **total strength** of each House
**Example**: Lok Sabha strength 545 → Need: (i) 2/3 of present & voting, (ii) 273+ (majority of 545)
scope: **No state ratification needed**: Parliament alone can amend
Covers **majority of constitutional provisions** not in Type 1 or Type 3
majorProvisions: **Fundamental Rights** (Part III) - except what affects federal structure
**All matters under Art 368** except those requiring state ratification
examples: **86th Amendment 2002**: Art 21A added (Right to Education) - Special majority
**97th Amendment 2011**: Co-operative societies (Art 19(1)(c), Part IXB) - Special majority
**101st Amendment 2016**: GST - Special majority + State ratification (Type 3)
importantPoints: **Majority of total strength**: Even if members absent, need 50%+ of total (not just present)
**Example**: If Lok Sabha = 545, and only 400 present → Need (i) 267+ votes (2/3 of 400), (ii) 273+ votes (majority of 545) → Must satisfy 273+
**Joint sitting NOT allowed**: Separate majority needed in each House
**No time limit**: Bill can be debated for any duration
content.examTips: **Special majority**: (i) 2/3 of present & voting, (ii) Majority of total strength - BOTH needed. Used for **most amendments** (FRs, DPSPs, etc.). No state ratification. Examples: Art 21A (86th), EWS quota (103rd).

definition: **Strictest method**: Special majority in Parliament + Ratification by at least **50% of state legislatures** (simple majority in state)
**Federal provisions**: Provisions affecting Centre-State relations require state consent
**Protects federalism**: States get veto power over amendments affecting their powers
provisionsRequiringThis: **3. Supreme Court & High Courts** (Chapter IV, V of Part V, Chapter V of Part VI):
• Composition, jurisdiction, powers of SC, HCs
**4. Distribution of legislative powers** (Chapter I of Part XI, Lists in 7th Schedule)
**7. Any matter in 7th Schedule** (Union, State, Concurrent Lists)
procedure: **Step 1**: Bill introduced in either House of Parliament
**Step 2**: Passed by **special majority** in both Houses
**Step 3**: Sent to **all state legislatures** for consideration
**Step 4**: At least **50% states** (simple majority in state) must ratify
**Step 5**: Bill presented to President for assent
**No time limit**: States can take any time; No deadline for ratification
importantPoints: **50% states**: Out of total states (currently 28); NOT 50% of those who vote
**Simple majority in states**: Not special majority
**No voting again**: Once state ratifies, cannot revoke (done deal)
**State rejection doesn't matter**: Only YES votes counted; If 14 states ratify out of 28, sufficient (rejections irrelevant)
**President cannot refuse**: Once Parliament passes, President must assent (Art 368(2))
examples: **7th Amendment 1956**: States Reorganisation Act - State boundaries changed
**24th Amendment 1971**: Parliament can amend FRs (Art 13, 368 amended) - State ratification
**42nd Amendment 1976**: Many provisions - Most controversial; State ratification obtained
**101st Amendment 2016**: GST - Overhauled taxation (7th Schedule changed); 50%+ states ratified
content.examTips: **Special majority + States**: For **federal provisions** (Art 54, 55, 73, 162, SC/HC, 7th Schedule, Lists). 50% states need to ratify (simple majority in state). Examples: GST (101st), 24th Amendment (Art 368), State reorganization (7th).

initiationOfBill: **Who can introduce**: Only in **Parliament** (NOT state legislatures)
**Minister or Private member**: Any MP can introduce (Government or Private Member Bill)
**Either House**: Can be introduced in Lok Sabha or Rajya Sabha
**No prior permission**: President's recommendation NOT required (unlike Money Bill, Ordinary Bills involving expenditure)
passageInParliament: • Second reading (Debate, clause by clause discussion)
**Special majority required**: In both Houses separately
**No joint sitting**: If one House rejects, Bill fails (unlike ordinary Bills where joint sitting possible)
**Deadlock**: If Rajya Sabha rejects, Bill dies (no mechanism to override)
stateRatification: **If required** (federal provisions): Sent to all states
**No time limit**: States can take any time
**50% states**: Need at least half of states to ratify
**Rejection irrelevant**: Only YES counted; NO doesn't matter
**Cannot withdraw**: Once ratified, state cannot revoke
presidentialAssent: **President MUST assent**: No discretion to refuse (Art 368(2))
**Cannot withhold**: Mandatory assent once Parliament passes
**Exception**: Only if SC declares amendment unconstitutional (basic structure violation)
uniqueFeatures: **No joint sitting**: Both Houses must pass separately; No deadlock resolution mechanism
**Rajya Sabha has equal power**: Unlike Money Bills where LS has supremacy
**President bound**: Unlike ordinary Bills where President has discretion
**Private member can initiate**: Unlike many countries where only government can propose constitutional amendments
**No referendum**: People not directly involved (unlike some countries)
content.examTips: **Procedure**: Any MP can introduce in either House. Special majority in both Houses (no joint sitting). If federal provisions, 50% states ratify. President MUST assent (no discretion). Rajya Sabha has equal power. No referendum.

articles.title: Shankari Prasad v Union of India (1951)

facts: **Year**: 1951 (First major case on amendment power)
**Challenge**: 1st Constitutional Amendment 1951 challenged
**1st Amendment**: Added Art 31A, 31B (Ninth Schedule); Protected land reforms; Response to Champakam case
**Issue**: Can Parliament amend Fundamental Rights? Does Art 13 limit Art 368?
**Petitioner**: Argued Art 13 ('law' includes amendment) prohibits FRs violation; Amendment violating FRs is void
art13Argument: **Art 13(2)**: 'State shall not make any **law** which takes away or abridges FRs; Any law in contravention with FRs shall be **void**'
**Petitioner's argument**: 'Law' in Art 13 includes constitutional amendments; So amendment violating FRs should be void
**Government's argument**: Art 13 applies only to ordinary laws, not constitutional amendments; Art 368 power separate
scJudgment: **5-judge bench**: Parliament has **unlimited power** to amend Constitution, including FRs
**Reasoning**: 'Law' in Art 13 means ordinary law, NOT constitutional amendment
**Art 368 separate**: Amendment power is different from legislative power; Art 13 doesn't limit Art 368
**FRs can be amended**: Parliament can amend any provision including FRs
**1st Amendment upheld**: Art 31A, 31B valid
significance: **Established**: Parliament's wide amendment power
**No limitation**: Court did not find any limitation on amendment power
**Encouraged amendments**: Opened door for future amendments to FRs
**Short-lived**: Later overruled by Kesavananda (1973) - Basic structure doctrine
content.examTips: **Shankari Prasad (1951)**: Parliament has **unlimited power** to amend, including FRs. Art 13 (law void if violates FR) doesn't apply to amendments. Later overruled by Kesavananda (1973). 1st Amendment upheld.

articles.title: Sajjan Singh v State of Rajasthan (1965)

facts: **Challenge**: 17th Constitutional Amendment 1964
**17th Amendment**: Expanded scope of Art 31A (land reforms protection); Added 44 Acts to Ninth Schedule
**Issue**: Can Parliament's amendment power be unlimited? Should Shankari Prasad be reconsidered?
scJudgment: **5-judge bench (3:2 verdict)**: Upheld 17th Amendment
**Majority view**: Followed Shankari Prasad; Parliament has power to amend entire Constitution
**Reasoning**: Constitution is supreme, not any part (including FRs); Parliament as constituent power can amend anything
**17th Amendment valid**: Expansion of Art 31A and Ninth Schedule upheld
dissentingView: **Justice Hidayatullah & Justice Mudholkar (dissent)**: Expressed **doubts** about unlimited amendment power
**Concern**: If Parliament can amend anything, it can destroy Constitution itself
**Suggestion**: Some limitations should exist on amendment power
**This dissent**: Later became basis for Basic Structure doctrine in Kesavananda
significance: **Reaffirmed**: Shankari Prasad - Unlimited amendment power
**BUT dissent important**: Seeds of Basic Structure doctrine planted
**Encouraged more amendments**: Government emboldened to make frequent amendments (24th, 25th, 29th, 42nd)
**Led to Kesavananda**: Excessive amendments led SC to reconsider in Kesavananda (1973)
content.examTips: **Sajjan Singh (1965)**: Reaffirmed Shankari Prasad - Parliament can amend entire Constitution. BUT **dissenting judges** (Hidayatullah, Mudholkar) expressed doubts about unlimited power - Seeds of Basic Structure doctrine. 17th Amendment upheld.

articles.title: Golak Nath v State of Punjab (1967)

facts: **Year**: 1967 (11-judge bench - overrule Shankari Prasad & Sajjan Singh)
**Challenge**: Punjab Land Reforms Acts placed in Ninth Schedule (17th Amendment)
**Issue**: Can Parliament amend Fundamental Rights?
**Background**: Series of amendments (1st, 4th, 17th) curtailing FRs; Concerns about unlimited amendment power
scJudgment: **6:5 majority**: Parliament **CANNOT amend Fundamental Rights**
**Revolutionary judgment**: Overruled Shankari Prasad and Sajjan Singh
**Reasoning**: FRs are 'transcendental and immutable' - Beyond amendment
**Art 13 includes amendments**: 'Law' in Art 13 includes constitutional amendments; Amendment violating FRs is void
**Amendment = law**: Parliament under Art 368 exercises legislative power, not constituent power; So Art 13 applies
keyHoldings: **FRs cannot be amended**: Parliament cannot amend Part III (Fundamental Rights)
**Prospective application**: This ruling applies to **future amendments only** (not past - past amendments valid)
**17th Amendment**: Upheld (already enacted; retrospective invalidation would cause chaos)
**Implication**: Parliament's hands tied; Cannot amend FRs in future
aftermath: **Government shocked**: This judgment paralyzed amendment power
**Political response**: Parliament passed **24th Amendment 1971** to overturn Golak Nath
**24th Amendment**: (i) Art 13 doesn't apply to amendments, (ii) Parliament can amend any part including FRs, (iii) Art 368 power is constituent power not legislative
**Led to Kesavananda**: 24th Amendment challenged → Kesavananda (1973) → Basic Structure doctrine
significance: **First limitation**: First time SC imposed limit on Parliament's amendment power
**FRs protected**: For first time, FRs declared unamendable
**Catalyst**: Led to 24th Amendment and eventually Kesavananda case
**Overruled by Kesavananda**: Kesavananda held FRs CAN be amended (but not destroy basic structure)
content.examTips: **Golak Nath (1967)**: Parliament **CANNOT amend FRs** (6:5 verdict, 11-judge bench). Overruled Shankari & Sajjan. FRs 'transcendental'. Prospective application. Led to **24th Amendment 1971** (overturn Golak Nath). Later overruled by Kesavananda (1973).

articles.title: Kesavananda Bharati v State of Kerala (1973)

facts: **Year**: 1973 (Largest bench - 13 judges)
**Challenge**: 24th, 25th, 29th Amendments (response to Golak Nath)
**24th Amendment**: Overturned Golak Nath - Parliament CAN amend FRs
**25th Amendment**: Art 31 amended - compensation for property acquisition; Art 31C added (DPSP over FR)
**29th Amendment**: Two Kerala land reform Acts added to Ninth Schedule
**Issue**: Extent of Parliament's amendment power?
scJudgment: **7:6 verdict**: **Basic Structure Doctrine** established
**Parliament CAN amend**: Any provision including FRs CAN be amended
**BUT limitation**: Cannot destroy **Basic Structure/Basic Features** of Constitution
**Golak Nath overruled**: FRs CAN be amended (Golak Nath was wrong)
**24th Amendment valid**: Parliament has power to amend FRs
basicStructure: **What is Basic Structure?** Essential features/character of Constitution
• Republican and democratic form of government
**Not exhaustive list**: SC can add more basic features in future cases
significance: **Most important** constitutional case in Indian history
**Balanced approach**: Parliament can amend (democracy) BUT cannot destroy essential features (constitutionalism)
**Saved democracy**: Prevented Parliament from destroying Constitution during Emergency
**Living doctrine**: Basic structure list expanded in later cases
**Global influence**: Adopted by Pakistan, Bangladesh, Malaysia, Belize, Uganda
aftermath: **42nd Amendment 1976** (Emergency): Tried to remove basic structure doctrine - Failed
**Minerva Mills 1980**: Reaffirmed and strengthened basic structure
**Waman Rao 1981**: Ninth Schedule amendments after 1973 can be reviewed for basic structure
**I.R. Coelho 2007**: Strengthened judicial review of Ninth Schedule
content.examTips: **MOST IMPORTANT CASE**: Kesavananda (1973) - **Basic Structure Doctrine** - Parliament CAN amend BUT cannot destroy basic structure. 13-judge bench, 7:6 verdict. Overruled Golak Nath. Examples: Supremacy, Rule of law, Federalism, Judicial review, FR-DPSP balance. Saved democracy.

articles.title: Minerva Mills v Union of India (1980)

facts: **Year**: 1980 (Emergency aftermath)
**Challenge**: 42nd Constitutional Amendment 1976 ('Mini Constitution')
**42nd Amendment changes**:
• Extended Art 31C to ALL DPSPs (not just Art 39(b), (c))
• Added clause: Laws implementing DPSPs cannot be challenged for violating FRs
• Art 368 clause: No amendment can be questioned on any ground in any court
**Issue**: Can Parliament make itself immune from judicial review?
scJudgment: **5-judge bench**: Struck down clauses of 42nd Amendment
**Art 31C extension struck down**: Giving ALL DPSPs primacy over FRs violates basic structure
**Reasoning**: **Balance between FRs and DPSPs** is basic feature; Cannot be destroyed
**Art 31C valid only for Art 39(b), (c)**: Not for all DPSPs
**Art 368 clause struck down**: Judicial review is basic feature; Cannot be removed
twoLungsTheory: **Justice Bhagwati's famous quote**: '*Indian Constitution is founded on the bedrock of the balance between Parts III and IV*'
**'Two lungs' analogy**: Constitution has **two lungs - FRs (Part III) and DPSPs (Part IV)**
Both lungs essential for life of Constitution
Cannot allow one lung to collapse to save the other
**Balance is basic structure**: Neither FRs nor DPSPs can have absolute supremacy
significance: **Strengthened basic structure**: Reaffirmed Kesavananda
**Limited Art 31C**: Scope reduced - Valid only for Art 39(b), (c)
**Judicial review protected**: Courts' power to review amendments reaffirmed
**Emergency excesses curbed**: 42nd Amendment's authoritarian provisions struck down
**FR-DPSP balance**: Explicitly declared as basic feature
content.examTips: **Minerva Mills (1980)**: 42nd Amendment partially struck down. **'Two lungs' theory** - FRs and DPSPs both essential; balance is basic structure. Art 31C valid only for Art 39(b), (c) - NOT all DPSPs. Judicial review protected. Strengthened Kesavananda.

articles.title: Waman Rao v Union of India (1981)

facts: **Issue**: Can Acts placed in **Ninth Schedule after Kesavananda** (1973) be reviewed for basic structure?
**Background**: Ninth Schedule (Art 31B) created to protect land reform laws from judicial review
**Dilemma**: Ninth Schedule immunity vs Basic Structure doctrine
scJudgment: **Bifurcated Ninth Schedule**:
**Before Apr 24, 1973** (Kesavananda date): Acts in Ninth Schedule **immune** - Cannot be challenged even for basic structure
**After Apr 24, 1973**: Acts can be **reviewed for basic structure** violation
**Reasoning**: Pre-Kesavananda Acts acquired immunity before basic structure doctrine came; Post-Kesavananda Acts must comply with basic structure
implications: **Post-1973 Acts vulnerable**: Can be struck down if violate basic structure
**Balanced approach**: Respected past Acts (legal certainty) but subjected future Acts to basic structure test
irCoelhoRefinement: 9-judge bench held even **post-1973 Ninth Schedule Acts** can be reviewed
If Act violates basic structure, Ninth Schedule immunity won't save it
Test: Whether Act violates basic structure (not just FRs)
content.examTips: **Waman Rao (1981)**: Ninth Schedule Acts **before Apr 24, 1973** (Kesavananda date) immune. Acts **after 1973** can be reviewed for basic structure. Later, **I.R. Coelho (2007)** strengthened review power - All Ninth Schedule Acts can be tested for basic structure.

decadeWise: **1970s**: 19 amendments - Most active decade; Emergency period; Fundamental changes (24th, 25th, 42nd, 44th)
**1990s**: 16 amendments - Economic liberalization, Panchayati Raj, women's reservation attempts
**2010s**: 15 amendments - GST implementation, Land acquisition, Judicial appointments (99th - struck down)
**2020s**: 6 amendments (till 2023) - EWS reservation (103rd), Extension of SC/ST/Anglo-Indian reservation
topThemes: **1. Property rights**: Most amended - 1st, 4th, 17th, 25th, 44th (Right to property removed)
controversialAmendments: **42nd Amendment 1976**: 'Mini Constitution' - Most controversial; Made during Emergency; Extended PM/Parliament power; Curtailed SC/HC powers; Removed property as FR; Changed Preamble (added 'Socialist', 'Secular', 'Integrity'); Extended Art 31C; Tried to limit judicial review - Many provisions struck down by Minerva Mills
**44th Amendment 1978**: Reversed many 42nd Amendment provisions; Restored fundamental rights; Removed right to property as FR (made legal right); Strengthened civil liberties
**99th Amendment 2014**: NJAC (National Judicial Appointments Commission) to replace Collegium system - **Struck down by SC** (2015) as violating basic structure (independence of judiciary)
**103rd Amendment 2019**: 10% EWS reservation - Challenged (pending) - Concern: Breaches 50% ceiling (Indra Sawhney), excludes social/educational backwardness criterion
failedAttempts: **Women's Reservation Bill**: Introduced multiple times (1996, 1998, 2010) - Not passed; 108th Amendment Bill passed in Rajya Sabha (2010) but lapsed in Lok Sabha
**Uniform Civil Code**: DPSP Art 44 - Never implemented; Too controversial
**Electoral reforms**: Many proposed amendments failed - State funding of elections, proportional representation, etc.
content.examTips: **Trends**: 106 amendments; 1970s most active (19 amendments - Emergency period). **Property rights** most amended topic. **42nd Amendment** most controversial ('Mini Constitution'). **99th Amendment (NJAC) struck down** by SC. Amendments show evolution from individual rights (1950s) to social welfare (1970s-2020s).

data.summary: **Constitutional Amendments**: **106 amendments** (till 2023) under **Art 368**. **Three types**: (1) Simple majority (federal, citizenship, elections), (2) Special majority (most amendments - FRs, DPSPs), (3) Special majority + 50% states (federal provisions - President election, SC/HC, 7th Schedule). **Key cases**: **Shankari Prasad (1951)** - Unlimited power; **Golak Nath (1967)** - Cannot amend FRs; **Kesavananda (1973)** - Basic Structure doctrine (can amend BUT not basic structure); **Minerva Mills (1980)** - Two lungs theory (FR-DPSP balance). **Most amended**: Property rights (1st, 4th, 17th, 25th, 44th). **42nd Amendment 1976** = 'Mini Constitution' (most controversial). **99th Amendment (NJAC) struck down** by SC (2015).
